metadata.titleEn: The MODIS remote sensing vegetation phenology at returning green stage in spring（2001-2014）
metadata.description: This dataset is based on the sixth edition of the MODIS normalized difference vegetation index  product (2001-2014) jointly released by NASA EOSDIS LP DAAC and the US Geological Survey USGS EROS. The NDVI has a time resolution of 16 days and a spatial resolution of 0.05 degree. First,the NDVI data products were re-sampled from the spatial resolution of 0.05 degree to 0.5 degree, then the time series of every year was smoothed by the double-logistic method, and the smoothed curvature was calculated. The maximum curvature of spring was selected as the returning green stage of the vegetation in Spring. This data can be used to analyze the temporal and spatial characteristics of the Holarctic vegetation phenology in Spring.

background: Vegetation phenology is the study of the seasonal life cycle of plants controlled by seasonal and interannual climate change. A shift in phenological timing has been documented in the past half century in response to ongoing climate change. The 5th Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change synthesized multiple studies to conclude that spring greenup (SG), the time at which plants begin to grow leaves in northern mid- and high-latitudes, has advanced at a rate of between 1.1 and 5.2 days decade-1 over different periods and regions. Temperature has long been recognized as the dominant factor that alters SG, and that its effects differ between plant species. Accurate representation of phenological processes in climate models is essential to predict mass and energy exchange between land and the atmosphere and the response of surface exchange processes to climate change.
research objective: In order to quantitatively evaluate the ESMs in modeling spring vegetation phenology and its responses to climate factors, we compare modeled spring phenology with satellite-inferred spring phenology in the northern temperate and boreal regions over 1982-2005. The main objectives of this work are to explore, across biomes and in observations and ESMs: (1) the preseason when climate exerts significant control on the SG, (2) the sensitivity of the SG to preseason temperature and precipitation, and (3) historical trends in the SG and their associated climate controls.
challenges: Large biases in individual ESMs for the preseason period, climate, and SG sensitivity imply needed model improvements to climate prediction and phenological process parameterizations. Multiple studies indicate that land surface schemes used in current ESMs do not place sufficient emphasis on accurately modeling seasonality of ecosystem processes that affect vegetation phenology. The discrepancies in preseason climate and its spatial and temporal trends indicate that constraints on spatial and temporal variations of preseason climate are weak.
methods: We use Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) generated from NOAA’s Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer data in the Global Inventory Monitoring and Modeling System (GIMMS) project over the 1982-2005 period, coupled with climate reanalysis (CRU-NCEP), to investigate the SG responses to preseason climate change in northern temperate and boreal regions. We compared these observed responses to the simulated SG responses to preseason climate inferred from the Earth System Models (ESMs) participating in the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5 (CMIP5) over 1982-2005. We used the first ensemble member from 11 ESMs to infer SG from monthly leaf area index (LAI) between 1982 and 2005, which we chose to be consistent with the period of GIMMS NDVI data. We regridded GIMMS NDVI3g data to half-degree resolution using a bilinear method to match the spatial resolution of the CRU-NCEP reanalysis. We determined the preseason following the method of Shen et al. (2014), but with a different climate reanalysis product and method for calculating the SG.
dataset: We used the latest version of the AVHRR instrument on board the NOAA satellite series NDVI dataset (GIMMS3g) which spans the period from July 1981 to December 2013, and has a spatial resolution of 1/12° and bimonthly temporal resolution. The daily mean temperature (Tm) and cumulative precipitation (Pc) are calculated from 6-hourly, half-degree resolution CRU-NCEP (Climate Research Unit-National Centers for Environmental Prediction) v6 reanalysis to analyze the preseason climate associated with SG derived from GIMMS NDVI.
findings: The observationally inferred SG suggests there has been an advance of about 1 day decade-1 between 1982 and 2005 in the northern mid- to high-latitudes, with significant spatial heterogeneity. Most ESMs, except BCC-CSM1, GFDL-ESM2G, and NorESM1-M, predicted advanced the SG north of the mid-latitudes, although the ESMs tended to predict larger SG advances than those from the GIMMS retrievals. The GIMMS-derived zonal mean SG advances throughout most of the 35-80°N latitude range. The GIMMS-derived SG indicates that the deciduous broadleaf forest biome has experienced the largest SG advance (3.1 days decade-1).

background: Vegetation phenology plays an important role in regulating land-atmosphere energy, water, and trace-gas exchanges. As the time spanned by satellite-based Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) products has increased to longer periods, several studies have used NDVI to derive spring greenup time (SG) at regional and global scales. Several changes in SG have been documented in the past half-century in response to ongoing climate change. The Northern Hemisphere SG has advanced in the range of 0-12 days per decade as inferred by NDVI. The wide range of SG shifts stem from studies covering different periods and regions, and different methods and datasets that have been applied to derive phenology metrics. Many factors associated with the obtaining of satellite data—e.g., drift of satellite orbits, calibration uncertainties, inter-satellite sensor differences, bidirectional and atmospheric effects—may cause uncertainties in satellite-derived data time series and thereby the uncertainties in interpreting the vegetation dynamics. Four NDVI products have been published based on radiances collected by the Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) instruments carried by programs of NOAA/NASA Pathfinder (PAL): Global Inventory Monitoring and Modeling Studies (GIMMS), Land Long Term Data Record (LTDR) version 3 (V3) and Fourier-Adjustment, Solar zenith angle corrected, Interpolated Reconstructed (FASIR). Each of these records extends back to the year 1981. Because of their long time span, the AVHRR NDVI products have been applied in numerous regional to global vegetation phenology studies. Advantages are recognized for GIMMS NDVI over the other AVHRR NDVI products to represent the temporal variation of NDVI.
research objective: Assessing the uncertainty in SG associated with different Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) products is essential for robustly interpreting the links between climate and phenological dynamics. We compare SG inferred from two NDVI products over the period 2001-2013: (1) Terra Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) and (2) National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA's) Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) instruments processed by the Global Inventory Monitoring and Modeling Studies (GIMMS) to explore confidence and uncertainty in the NDVI-inferred SG trend and its links to climate variability.
challenges: Many factors associated with the obtaining of satellite data—e.g., drift of satellite orbits, calibration uncertainties, inter-satellite sensor differences, bidirectional and atmospheric effects—may cause uncertainties in satellite-derived data time series and thereby the uncertainties in interpreting the vegetation dynamics.
methods: We used an independent climate reanalysis dataset to analyze the preseason, the period preceding SG during which the climate drivers regulate SG, and the sensitivity between preseason climate and SG.
dataset: We compare SG inferred from two NDVI products over the period 2001-2013: (1) Terra Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) and (2) National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA's) Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) instruments processed by the Global Inventory Monitoring and Modeling Studies (GIMMS).
findings: Both MODIS and GIMMS agreed in showing an advancement of SG in northern Canada, the eastern United States, and Russia, as well as a delay in SG in western North America, parts of Baltic Europe and East Asia. In the regions with advanced SG, GIMMS inferred much weaker advancement whereas in the regions with delayed SG, GIMMS inferred much stronger delay than MODIS. This resulted in a GIMMS SG delay in both North America and Eurasia. MODIS data show no significant SG shift in North American for spatial heterogeneity in SG shift, but dominant SG advancement in Eurasia. The SG advancement inferred from MODIS is associated with a stronger coupling between SG and temperature and a stronger sensitivity across biomes as compared to GIMMS. The main uncertainty in the SG trend and SG-temperature sensitivity are in northern high latitudes (>50°N) where GIMMS and MODIS show different magnitude and sign of the annual SG anomalies.

Definition.Question: What are the common challenges associated with using satellite-derived data time series for studying vegetation dynamics?
Definition.Answer: Challenges include drift of satellite orbits, calibration uncertainties, inter-satellite sensor differences, bidirectional and atmospheric effects, all of which may cause uncertainties in satellite-derived data time series and thereby affect the interpretation of vegetation dynamics.

Definition.Question: What is the 'double-logistic method' used for in the context of MODIS NDVI data processing?
Definition.Answer: The double-logistic method is used to smooth time series data of NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index) and calculate the curvature to determine the spring greenup period by identifying the maximum curvature in spring, allowing for the analysis of vegetation phenological characteristics.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for NDVI using MODIS compare to those using the AVHRR instruments in terms of temporal and spatial resolution?
Comparison.Answer: MODIS NDVI products have a temporal resolution of 16 days and a spatial resolution of 0.05 degrees, which was resampled to 0.5 degrees for certain analyses. In contrast, the AVHRR NDVI dataset (GIMMS3g) spans from July 1981 to December 2013, with a spatial resolution of 1/12° and a bimonthly temporal resolution. These differences impact the granularity and temporal coverage of the vegetation phenology data.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the challenges associated with using MODIS and GIMMS NDVI data for studying spring greenup (SG) trends?
Comparison.Answer: Both MODIS and GIMMS NDVI datasets face challenges due to satellite data acquisition factors such as calibration uncertainties and inter-satellite sensor differences. However, the challenges differ in their impact on the SG trends. For instance, GIMMS inferred a weaker advancement in regions with SG advancement and a stronger delay in regions with SG delay compared to MODIS, leading to differing interpretations of SG trends, especially in northern high latitudes.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges arise from the use of satellite-derived data in understanding the links between climate and vegetation dynamics?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges associated with satellite-derived data include uncertainties caused by factors such as satellite orbit drift, calibration uncertainties, and inter-satellite sensor differences. These issues can impact the accuracy of time series data, leading to uncertainties in interpreting vegetation dynamics and trends. For example, discrepancies in SG trends between MODIS and GIMMS data highlight the potential for differing interpretations based on the dataset used.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the methods for calculating spring greenup (SG) from satellite data be improved to enhance the accuracy of phenology models?
Interpretation.Answer: Improvements in calculating SG from satellite data might involve refining the methods used to determine the preseason climate conditions that influence SG. For instance, employing different climate reanalysis products or enhancing model parameterizations can address large biases in Earth System Models (ESMs) related to preseason periods and climate sensitivity. By strengthening constraints on spatial and temporal variations, more accurate phenological models can be developed.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do uncertainties in satellite-derived data time series arise in the context of vegetation phenology studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Uncertainties in satellite-derived data time series arise due to factors associated with obtaining satellite data, such as drift of satellite orbits, calibration uncertainties, inter-satellite sensor differences, and bidirectional and atmospheric effects. These factors may affect the reliability of interpreting vegetation dynamics.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the variation in the sensitivity of spring greenup to preseason temperature and precipitation across different biomes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variation in the sensitivity of spring greenup to preseason temperature and precipitation across different biomes is influenced by differences in plant species and their varying responses to climate factors. The preseason climate conditions exert significant control on spring greenup, and these effects differ based on the ecological characteristics of each biome.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the large biases observed in Earth System Models when modeling spring vegetation phenology?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Large biases in Earth System Models for modeling spring vegetation phenology are contributed by insufficient emphasis on accurately modeling seasonality of ecosystem processes, weak constraints on spatial and temporal variations of preseason climate, and discrepancies in preseason climate and its trends. These biases imply a need for model improvements in climate prediction and phenological process parameterizations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes might result from regridding NDVI data to a different spatial resolution in terms of monitoring vegetation phenology?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Regridding NDVI data to a different spatial resolution, such as from 0.05 degrees to 0.5 degrees, could impact the monitoring of vegetation phenology by potentially reducing the granularity and detail of spatial data. This may affect the accuracy of phenological metrics like spring greenup timing, especially in heterogeneous landscapes where finer spatial resolution would capture more local variations.

Causal Consequence.Question: How could the use of different satellite sensors impact the consistency and reliability of vegetation phenology datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using different satellite sensors, such as MODIS and AVHRR, could lead to inconsistencies in vegetation phenology datasets due to factors like sensor calibration differences, orbit drift, and atmospheric effects. These inconsistencies may result in variations in inferring phenological events such as spring greenup, affecting the reliability of long-term trend analyses across different regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of employing MODIS and AVHRR NDVI datasets for analyzing vegetation spring greenup trends?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objectives include assessing the uncertainty in spring greenup (SG) associated with different NDVI products and exploring the confidence and uncertainty in the NDVI-inferred SG trend and its links to climate variability.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of analyzing the sensitivity between preseason climate and spring greenup using independent climate reanalysis datasets?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Analyzing this sensitivity is crucial for understanding how climate drivers regulate SG in the preseason, which helps in robustly interpreting the links between climate and phenological dynamics, thereby improving climate models and predictions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in resampling NDVI data from a spatial resolution of 0.05 degrees to 0.5 degrees for vegetation phenology analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The NDVI data product is resampled from 0.05 degrees spatial resolution to 0.5 degrees before applying a double-logistic method for smoothing and calculating curvature to determine the spring greenup period of vegetation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are the biases in Earth System Models addressed when modeling spring vegetation phenology?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Large biases in individual Earth System Models for the preseason period, climate, and SG sensitivity indicate needed improvements in climate prediction and phenological process parameterizations. Constraints on spatial and temporal variations of preseason climate are noted as weak, which implies a need for model improvements.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What process is employed to compare spring greenup inferred from different NDVI products to assess trends and uncertainties?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Spring greenup is compared using NDVI products from MODIS and AVHRR instruments processed by GIMMS over the period 2001-2013. An independent climate reanalysis dataset is used to analyze the preseason and the sensitivity between preseason climate and SG.

Enablement.Question: What factors enabled the use of satellite-derived NDVI data for analyzing vegetation phenology over long time periods?
Enablement.Answer: The use of satellite-derived NDVI data for analyzing vegetation phenology over long time periods is enabled by the availability of satellite instruments like NOAA’s Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) and MODIS, which provide long-term data records. These instruments capture radiances that can be processed into NDVI products, facilitating the study of vegetation dynamics over decades.

Enablement.Question: What challenges in satellite data acquisition and processing need to be addressed to enable reliable interpretation of vegetation dynamics?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges in satellite data acquisition and processing that need to be addressed include satellite orbit drift, calibration uncertainties, inter-satellite sensor differences, and atmospheric effects. These factors can introduce uncertainties in NDVI time series, making it crucial to refine data collection and processing methods to enable reliable interpretation of vegetation dynamics.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be different magnitudes and directions of SG trends when comparing MODIS and GIMMS datasets?
Expectation.Answer: MODIS and GIMMS datasets show different magnitudes and directions of SG trends due to potential uncertainties caused by factors like satellite orbit drift, calibration uncertainties, and sensor differences, which affect the interpretation of vegetation dynamics.

Expectation.Question: What are the reasons for the large biases in individual Earth System Models (ESMs) when predicting preseason climate and SG sensitivity?
Expectation.Answer: Large biases in individual ESMs could stem from inadequate emphasis on accurately modeling seasonality of ecosystem processes that affect vegetation phenology and weak constraints on spatial and temporal variations of preseason climate.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of the double-logistic method in smoothing NDVI time series for analyzing vegetation phenology across diverse biomes?
Judgmental.Answer: The double-logistic method is used to smooth NDVI time series, which aids in calculating the curvature and identifying the spring greenup period. This approach is effective as it helps in analyzing the spatial and temporal characteristics of vegetation phenology across the pan-Arctic region. However, the effectiveness may vary depending on the biome and specific characteristics of the region under study.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges and uncertainties associated with using satellite-derived NDVI data for assessing spring greenup trends?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges and uncertainties in using satellite-derived NDVI data include factors such as satellite orbit drift, calibration uncertainties, inter-satellite sensor differences, bidirectional and atmospheric effects. These issues can lead to uncertainties in the derived data time series, affecting the interpretation of vegetation dynamics and spring greenup trends.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how does regridding NDVI data to match different spatial resolutions impact the accuracy of phenological studies?
Judgmental.Answer: Regridding NDVI data to match different spatial resolutions, such as from 0.05-degree to 0.5-degree, is essential for consistency with other datasets like climate reanalysis. While this process allows for integrated analysis across multiple datasets, it may introduce interpolation errors and potentially affect the accuracy of phenological studies, especially in regions with high spatial variability in vegetation.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about what challenges exist in using satellite-derived data for analyzing vegetation dynamics, especially concerning spring greenup.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in using satellite-derived data include calibration uncertainties, inter-satellite sensor differences, bidirectional and atmospheric effects, all of which can introduce uncertainties in interpreting vegetation dynamics and phenological metrics like spring greenup.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how different datasets, like MODIS and GIMMS, compare or complement each other in capturing spring greenup trends.
Assertion.Answer: MODIS and GIMMS datasets show both agreement and differences in capturing spring greenup trends. They agree on some regional advancements, but GIMMS tends to infer weaker advancements or stronger delays compared to MODIS, highlighting uncertainties in data interpretation.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges associated with satellite data collection for vegetation phenology studies and how these challenges impact the interpretation of phenological dynamics.
Request/Directive.Answer: Many factors associated with the obtaining of satellite data—such as drift of satellite orbits, calibration uncertainties, inter-satellite sensor differences, bidirectional and atmospheric effects—may cause uncertainties in satellite-derived data time series. These uncertainties affect the interpretation of vegetation dynamics, making it difficult to robustly link climate changes to phenological shifts.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methods used to infer spring greenup time (SG) from NDVI datasets and how these methods may vary in their sensitivity and accuracy.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methods used to infer SG from NDVI datasets include smoothing NDVI time series with techniques like the double-logistic method and determining climate influences using climate reanalysis datasets. The sensitivity and accuracy of these methods can vary, as shown by the differences between MODIS and GIMMS datasets, where GIMMS often shows weaker or stronger SG shifts compared to MODIS, indicating different sensitivities and potential uncertainties in the inferred phenological trends.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss potential datasets that could be used for analyzing spring vegetation phenology and the historical trends in SG, and the benefits each dataset might offer.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for analyzing spring vegetation phenology and historical trends in SG include the MODIS NDVI products, NOAA's AVHRR NDVI products processed by GIMMS, and climate reanalysis datasets like CRU-NCEP. MODIS offers high temporal and spatial resolution, which can be beneficial for detailed analyses. GIMMS provides a long historical record, useful for trend analysis. Climate reanalysis datasets provide essential climate variables, allowing researchers to explore the relationships between climate factors and phenological changes.
